subject: Re: [junit] How to write effective tests?
msgSnippet: Kent Beck s TDD by Example. So said  Lee Chalupa  on  2003-01-21 -------------------- ... into ... you ... it, ... first ... the ... cellspacing=0
messageBody:
Kent Beck's TDD by Example.

So said Lee Chalupa on 2003-01-21 --------------------

>Can anyone point me towards a book that give some practical insights
into
>the thinking process a programmer goes through to write a good set of
>tests?
>
>Thanks
>
>lee
>
>
>
>On Tue, 21 Jan 2003 11:41:47 +0900 (JST), Curt Sampson
><yahoo_sucks@...>
> wrote:
>
>> <html><body>
>>
>>
>> <tt>
>> On Mon, 20 Jan 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:<BR>
>> <BR>
>> > Generally speaking, you don't really know these things until
you
>> write<BR>
>> > test code, which is really just sample client code, look at
it,<BR>
>> > evaluate it and move on. In general, it is when one sees it
>"in
>> print"<BR>
>> > than one really looks at it carefully. Writing the test
first<BR>
>> > guarantees this, while writing the stub first does not.<BR>
>> <BR>
>> Actually, another point I forgot to mention is that writing the
>> testing<BR>
>> code first gets you writing testable code faster. I know that when
>> I'm<BR>
>> writing unit tests for legacy code, I frequently have to change
the<BR>
>> design of the code so I can test it more easily.<BR>
>> <BR>
>> cjs<BR>
>> -- <BR>
>> Curt Sampson  <cjs@...>   +81 90 7737
>> 2974   <a
>> href="http://www.netbsd.org">http://www.netbsd.org</a><BR>
>>     Don't you know, in this new Dark Age, we're all
>> light.  --XTC<BR>
>> <BR>
>> <BR>
>> </tt>
>>
>> <br>
>>
